p: Lignans from wild relatives of sesame that are not present in S. indicum are (+)-sesangolin, (+)-alatumin, (+)-2-episesalatin, and (+)-7′-episesantalin ( Table 2). Furofuran lignan (+)-sesangolin was purified from S. angolense in a search for new synergists because seed oil of S. angolense possessed unusually high synergistic activity with pyrethrum [ 91]. Sesangolin was later reported from S. angustifolium [ 87], S. alatum [ 88], and S. radiaum [ 92]. Both alatumin [ 89] and episesalatin [ 90] were found in S. alatum. The most recent contribution to the diversity of sesame lignans is (+)-7′-episesantalin, which was purified from S. radiatum [ 92].
